Award.AwardTitle: CRII: RI: Assignment, Routing, and Coordination of Diverse Robotic Sensors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the coordination of diverse robotic sensors by focusing on the task of observing all points in a given environment. The robots are required to visit viewpoints, such that all the viewpoints collectively observe the environment. When the number of potential viewpoints exceeds the number of robots, some robots will be required to visit and cover multiple viewpoints. Not all viewpoints are reachable from all the robots.

This project introduces a novel combination of assignment and routing problems with diversity constraints. These investigations lay the foundations to achieve the overarching goal of understanding the role of diversity in robot swarms. The PI works with the Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity at Virginia Tech to ensure broad outreach, in particular, to K-12 students and for promoting diversity in STEM recruitment.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many critical applications, robots can be used as mobile sensors for efficient data gathering. In particular, applications such as inspecting bridges for defects, search-and-rescue, and situational awareness of first responders can benefit from having robots as mobile cameras. Depending on the environment, a single robot or a single type of robot may not be sufficient. Instead, we may need robots with complementary capabilities (such as aerial and ground robots) for efficient sensing. The goal of this project was to investigate algorithms for enabling coordination between robots with heterogeneous sensing capabilities.

Intellectual Merit

The PI and his students have developed new algorithms for teams of aerial and ground robots to efficienty survey regions of interest. Our algorithms are able to take into account the different sensing capabilities of aerial and ground robots as well as their respective limitations. A noteworthy limitation we investigated is that aerial robots have significantly less battery lifetime than ground robots. Our algorithms leverage ground robots as mobile recharging stations, in addition to acting as ground-based sensors. We designed algorithms for monitoring indoor, structured environments as well as outdoor terrains. The algorithms were evaluated through theoretical proofs of performance guarantees, extensive simulations, as well as field experiments with drones and ground robots.

Broader Impacts

Dissemination: All research results are disseminated via publications at top-tier robots venues. These publications are also freely available on the lab website: https://www.raas.ece.vt.edu/publications/

Software produced as part of this project has been released to the community (along with the respective publications) via the PI's github repository: https://github.com/raaslab

The PI has given numerous presentations of the work done as part of this project via invited seminars at other universities and conferences.

Students Training and Professional Development: Three MS students funded by this project have completed his thesis. Two of them have gone on to work for Apple and the third continued as a PhD student with the PI. Another PhD student supported by this project recently completed his PhD proposal and is expected to graduate in Fall 2019.

Outreach: The PI and his group participated in multiple outreach activities in coordination with the Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity (CEED) at Virginia Tech and the National Society of Black Engineer?s Pre-College Initiative throughout the duration of this project. Middle and high school students participated in a ?hide-and-seek? game using remotely operated ground and aerial robots where they were introduced to the concept of viewpoint planning through a learning activity. The robotic testbed developed as part of this project was used for the hands-on activities.

Modified by: Pratap Tokekar
